--- title: "INFO 511 - Group Final Project" subtitle: "Proposal: Milestone 2" author: - name: "Indecision Scientists" affiliations: - name: "College of Information Science, University of Arizona" format: html: code-tools: true code-overflow: wrap code-line-numbers: true embed-resources: true editor: visual code-annotations: hover execute: warning: false jupyter: python3 --- ::: {#load-pkgs .cell message='false' execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import numpy as np import seaborn as sns import pandas as pd ``` ::: ## Introduction and data For each data set: - Identify the source of the data. - State when and how it was originally collected (by the original data curator, not necessarily how you found the data). - Write a brief description of the observations. - Address ethical concerns about the data, if any. Make sure to load the data and use inline code for some of this information. 1. **Remote Work & Mental Health** - **Source:** Kaggle - - **Collection date/method:** \[When/how originally collected by data curator\] - **Description:** \[Brief description of observations\] - **Ethical concerns:** \[Ethical concerns about data, if any\] ::: {#222f9010 .cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} #Make sure to load the data and use inline code for some of this information. ``` ::: 2. **U.S. Natural Resources Revenue (2003-2023)** - **Source:** Kaggle - - **Collection date/method:** \[When/how originally collected by data curator\] - **Description:** \[Brief description of observations\] - **Ethical concerns:** \[Ethical concerns about data, if any\] ::: {#b68a9db2 .cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} #Make sure to load the data and use inline code for some of this information. ``` ::: 3. **Global Earthquake Data** - **Source:** Kaggle - - **Collection date/method:** \[When/how originally collected by data curator\] - **Description:** \[Brief description of observations\] - **Ethical concerns:** \[Ethical concerns about data, if any\] ::: {#b025a19e .cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} quakes = pd.read_csv("data/earthquakes.csv") ``` ::: ## Research Question Your research question should contain at least three variables, and should be a mix of categorical and quantitative variables. When writing a research question, please think about the following: - What is your target population? - Is the question original? - Can the question be answered? For each data set, include the following: - A well formulated research question. (You may include more than one research question if you want to receive feedback on different ideas for your project. However, one per data set is required.) - Statement on why this question is important. - A description of the research topic along with a concise statement of your hypotheses on this topic. - Identify the types of variables in your research question. Categorical? Quantitative? 1. **Remote Work & Mental Health** - **Research question:** \[A well formulated research question requiring at least 3 variables with a mix of categorical and quantitative data types\] - **Importance:** \[Statement on why this question is important\] - **Description:** \[A description of the research topic along with a concise statement of your hypotheses on this topic\] - **Variable types:** \[Identify the types of variables in your research question. Categorical? Quantitative?\] 2. **U.S. Natural Resources Revenue (2003-2023)** - **Research question:** \[A well formulated research question requiring at least 3 variables with a mix of categorical and quantitative data types\] - **Importance:** \[Statement on why this question is important\] - **Description:** \[A description of the research topic along with a concise statement of your hypotheses on this topic\] - **Variable types:** \[Identify the types of variables in your research question. Categorical? Quantitative?\] 3. **Global Earthquake Data** - **Research question:** Can we predict the impact and measure of an earthquake based on various factors, such as location, date, time, magnitude, or depth? - **Importance:** It would be nice to predict the impact of an earthquake to give estimations on recovery times/efforts needed by local governments if they we can accurately predict the impact. - **Description:** This topic covers earthquake data from around the world. Our hypothesis would be: you can predict the measure of impact an earthquake has based on various features of an earthquake. - **Variable types:** - Time and date: object - Magnitude, depth, felt, cdi, mmi, sig, rms, gap: number - Continent, country, alert: categorical ## Glimpse of data For each data set: - Place the file containing your data in the data folder of the project repo. - Use the `.head()` and `.info()` functions to provide a glimpse of the data set. 1. **Remote Work & Mental Health** ::: {#dda19aef .cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} #use head() and info() after loading data set ``` ::: 2. **U.S. Natural Resources Revenue (2003-2023)** ::: {#06b282e1 .cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} #use head() and info() after loading data set ``` ::: 3. **Global Earthquake Data** ::: {#a4b9add4 .cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} quakes.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ```{=html}
